reviewText:
Bobby and Jimmy are two eagle scouts who, through acts of bravery, win trips to South America to visit fellow scouts there. So how do they get there? Aboard Mr. Mac's little bi-plane in which they have to share a cramped cockpit seat while encountering a fierce storm and then running out of gas  until they crash in the Amazon jungle. Mr. Mac has a bad foot sprain and Bobby and Jimmy set out for help. The serial follows our two heroes and their stowaway dog "Johnson" as they battle natives, bandits, wild animals and the elements while Mr. Mac contracts a fever and stumbles around aimlessly for most of the remaining chapters.
This serial was lots of fun to watch especially since the main leads are two rather ordinary kids. Bobby (Bobby Cox, not the Atlanta Braves manager) is a chubby little tyke who always wants to eat but is very smart and can get out of any jam, and Jim (Jim Vance) is a tall skinny kid who is likewise with the smarts, and the two make a great team whether foiling a native sacrifice or blowing up a bandit hideout.
I have both available editions of this serial and I will say that the re-mastered version is generally cleaner, however the version offered by ALPHA isn't too bad either. Both have alot of the same flaws, contrast issues most noticible. I sometimes alternated dvds for chapter comparison and forgot which one I was watching. So I would say you can purchase either and enjoy it, though I would recommend the 2-disc restored version if you don't mind spending the extra bucks.
This is a fun old serial and I enjoyed it, only issue it won't play on my blu-ray player whilst all my other DVD's do, suggests they are not using standardised formatting, it works on PC.
I saw this series when I was in the 7th grade.  It was old then.  It gave me many ideas and reinforced values which I have used ever since.

VCI Entertainment and First Division Pictures present..."YOUNG EAGLES" (1934) (Dolby digitally remastered), a 12 Chapter cliffhanger from an action packed '30s serial era under director's Spencer Gordon Bennet (chapter 1), Vin Moore (chapters 2-4) and Edward Lavier (chapters 5-12), producer Ashton Dearholt and George W. Stout, adaptation by Elizabeth Hayter, story and screenplay by Harry O. Hoyt....cast includes Carter Dixon (Angus MacLean, the aviator),  Bobby Cox (Robert 'Bobby' Ford), Jim Vance (James Francis 'Jim' Adams), Bob Ferrey (Speedy, native guide), Iron Eyes Cody (Temple Guard), Jules Cowles (Pinardo Henchman-Guard), Earl Dwire (William Thayer), Frank Lackteen (Temple Guard), Merrill McCormick( Jos Pinardo ), Philo McCullough (Nicholas Condylos),. . . . . our story brings to the viewer natives, pirates, wild animals and our trust worthy small boy scout heroes Bobby Cox and Jim Vance along with Carter Dixon the daring pilot...their plane crashes in the jungles of South America as they stuble upon an explorer who shares with them a treasure map...where are the government authorities when you need them, not to mention the crooked trader villains Philo McCullough and Merrill McCormick who in most of the serial a scene stealers...good to see one of my old favorite character actors Earl Dwire who is only in Chapter Three "City of the Dead"...don't touch that dial until the final serial chapter "Out of the Sky"...it took three directors Bennet, Lavier and Moore to finish this 12 Chapter Cliffhanger, but they were well worth it. . . . .there is a great deal of entertainment here for the cliffhanger fans out there...all courtesy of VCI Entertainment, who in my humble opinion is the best there is in restoring early serials and features.

CHAPTER TITLES:

1. The Crash

2. The Drums of Hate

3. City of the Dead

4. Bridge of Doom

5. Treasure Trails

6. Fangs of Flame

7. Tropic Fury

8. Wings of Terror

9. The Lost Lagoon

10. Jungle Outlaws

11. Trapped

13. Out of the Sky

If you're into vintage serials as I am, why not pick up a copy of the following titles from VCI Home Video:

VCI CLIFFHANGER TRAILERS:

1. Adventures of Red Ryder (Don "Red" Barry)

2. Adventures of the Flying Cadets (Bobby Jordan)

3. Buck Rogers (Buster Crabbe)

4. Captain Midnight (Dave O'Brien)

5. Captain Video: Master of the Stratosphere (Judd Holdren & I. Stanford Jolley)

6. Dick Tracy's G-Men (Ralph Byrd)

7. Don Winslow of the Navy (Don Terry)

8. Don Winslow of the Coast Guard (Don Terry)

9. Drums of Fu Manchu (Henry Brandon)

10. Fighting Kit Carson (Johnny Mack Brown)

11. Flash Gordon Conquers the Universe (Buster Crabbe)

12. The Green Archer (Victory Jory)

13. Jungle Girl (Frances Gifford)

14. Jungle Jim (Grant Withers & Raymond Hatton)

15. Lost City of the Jungle (Russell Hayden & Keye Luke)

16. Mandrake the Magician (Warren Hull & Dick Curtis)

17. Miracle Rider (Tom Mix & Tony Jr)

18. The Painted Stallion (Ray "Crash" Corrigan)

19. The Phantom (Tom Tyler)

20. The Return of Chandu (Bela Lugosi)

21. Riders of Death Valley (Dick Foran, Leo Carrillo & Buck Jones)

22. Secret Agent X-9 (1937) (Scott Kolk & Henry Brandon)

23. Secret Agent X-9 (1945) (Lloyd Bridges & Keye Luke)

24. Sky Raiders (Donald Woods & Billy Halop)

25. Undersea Kingdom (Ray "Crash" Corrigan)

26. Winners of the West (Dick Foran, Harry Woods, Roy Barcroft & Charles Stevens)

27. Zane Greys "King of the Royal Mounted" (Allan "Rocky" Lane)

28. Zorro's Cliffhanger Collection (Reed Hadley, John Carroll & Linda Stirling)

Great job by VCI Entertainment for releasing "Young Eagles" (1934), the digital transfere with a clean, clear and crisp print...looking forward to more high quality releases from the vintage serial era of the '30s, '40s & '50s...order your copy now from Amazon or VCI Entertainment where there are plenty of copies available on VHS, stay tuned once again for top notch action mixed with deadly adventure from the "King of Serials" VCI...just the way we like 'em

Total Time: 228 mins on 2 VHS ~ VCI Entertainment 1740 ~ (6/25/2002)

This serial is a mess.

The serial looks like it was converted from a used VHS tape to digital.  Not that this would rate one star if the movie was interesting and fun to watch, but this one wasn't, it just made a poor movie unwatchable.

The plot is sub-par, the acting sub-par, and the story line sub-par.  The lead looks like Spanky McFarland from the 'Our Gang" movies, which is really convenient due to the fact this movie is a mash of "Our Gang". "Jungle Jim".and "Bomba", and that isn't even fair to the mentioned films because they are fun to watch, this one isn't.

Save your money and your time.  If you must watch a Boy Scout movie, stick with Clifton Webb's "The Scoutmaster;" Disney's "Follow Me Boys," and the indy "Scout Camp."  And if you need to read about scouts I recommend Kindles collection of "The Boy Scout Megapack" by Herbert Carter  Twelve stories featuring the Silver Beaver patrol presented in a series, combined into twelve books.  All superior stories compared to this and fun to read.
This film mostly proganda for scouting. But it shows the useful for those not familiar with it.it editing is heavily dated. But still enjoyable.

This DVD series deserves Archive Status.  At first, this series could only be viewed at a Movie Theatre during a Matinee in the 1930s.
In addition, the actor Carter Dixon, and the boy actors Bobby Cox and Jim Vance were natural without a lot of Hollywood fluff.  A young boy could not to a Narnia where Boy Scouts were on adventures in Central America which involved treasure-hunters, dangerous beasts and savage natives.  Iron Eyes Cody's acting debut as a native was interesting.  When I was a young Boy Scout in the 1950s, living in New York, I remember watching this series in TV reruns.  Most noteworthy was how the boys put their scouting skills to the ultimate test to survive.  This is a movie series for the young to benefit and a good Archive item in a DVD Collection.
I was surprised this serial was so old, 1937ish and in remarkable good condition for such an old film....interesting...O K
My step-son really likes this collection! The adventure and excitement of the boys' adventure through the wild and the dangers they come against- very exciting adventures!

When the day comes that all we have is junk on TV, Oh that day is here, we can turn to the movies with a message without the need for violence, profanity or sex.  The scouts love to sit and watch the series.  Just recently gave them a taste of the first two chapters and they left the meeting wanting more.  Use it as a reward, a lesson or just plain fun.  Very enjoyable.

The picture on the front was misleading since this was a very very old black & white.  It is a dozen or so episodes of an old TV show.  We laughed hysterically because so much of it is sooo non-realistic and the situations are nothing our current Boy Scouts would/could ever get theirselves into.  But, watching it in the context of pure entertainment and not a Scout lesson, then I'll give it 4 stars.
